prompt.p: In patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, the packed cell volume (PCV; i.e. haematocrit) is often raised.

choiceInteraction.simpleChoice: The ratio of the volume of red blood cells to the volume of whole blood
The size of red blood cells
The risk of blood clot formation
The percentage of haemoglobin saturated with oxygen
The fraction of plasma capable of carrying oxygen

modalFeedback.p:
Option A (The ratio of the volume of red blood cells to the volume of whole blood) is Correct. The ratio of the volume of red blood cells to the volume of whole blood is referred to as the haematocrit and is usually between 0.36 and 0.53. When oxygen levels are low (as in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, high altitude and other situations), the kidneys respond to low oxygen tension by increasing the production of erythropoietin and thus the number of red cells (polycythaemia), which increases the packed cell volume (haematocrit).
Option B (The size of red blood cells) is Incorrect. The size of red blood cells is referred to as the mean corpuscular volume (MCV).
Option C (The risk of blood clot formation) is Incorrect. The risk of blood clot formation is indicated by the prothrombin time.
Option D (The percentage of haemoglobin saturated with oxygen) is Incorrect. The percentage of haemoglobin saturated with oxygen is measured by pulse oximetry.
Option E (The fraction of plasma capable of carrying oxygen) is Incorrect. The amount of oxygen dissolved in plasma is very small.
